ground_truth: Gandhi sits cross-legged, listening in a way that opens the heart, while behind him a mass of villagers waits stoically outside the dwelling for their case to be heard. Meha tries to speak unemotionally, but under Gandhi's sympathetic gaze, his despair breaks through. Near breakdown, Meha gestures around the empty house, unable to continue, and he nods. Gandhi looks around the crude dwelling where almost nothing remains. Two young men, perhaps seventeen and older, a girl about sixteen, and Meha's wife, sitting near Ba, are present. The two women listen together, but Meha's wife looks defeated, with unkempt hair and a dirty sari. Gandhi nods, speaking bleak words that offer no false hope, and glances at Meha's wife, who lowers her head as water comes to her eyes. Ba comforts her, and the woman breaks down into sobs. Later, Gandhi rides in an open howdah on an elephant, lost in sober reflection, with Shukla by his side, too intimidated to interrupt Gandhi's dark mood, which contains more anger than seen before except towards Ba. A ball is hit, revealing a lush, verdant pitch where white-garbed players and English onlookers watch under parasols, with Indian servants discreetly serving drinks. After a four is hit, a batsman notices a car hurrying near the clubhouse with an officer and streaming people, an Indian corporal driving, as a major stands on the back seat. The captain, wearing a clerical collar, determined, looks down at Gandhi and shakes his head. Gandhi is seen in full, in a white loincloth, shawl, and sandals, his attire for life. Charlie studies Gandhi, understands, and grins, prompting a small grin from Gandhi, who laughs, and laughs again. Charlie turns to the guard, who hesitantly unlocks the cell. Charlie enters, sits on a stool opposite Gandhi, his long legs awkwardly filling the space between them.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Gandhi perches cross-legged, hearing in a manner that unlocks the soul, while behind him a throng of villagers waits stoically outside the abode for their issue to be attended. Meha attempts to speak dispassionately, but under Gandhi's compassionate gaze, his hopelessness surfaces. Near collapse, Meha gestures around the vacant house, unable to proceed, and he nods. Gandhi gazes around the primitive abode where nearly nothing remains. Two young males, perhaps seventeen and older, a girl about sixteen, and Meha's spouse, sitting near Ba, are present. The two women hear together, but Meha's spouse appears defeated, with disheveled hair and a grimy sari. Gandhi nods, articulating bleak expressions that present no false promise, and glances at Meha's spouse, who lowers her head as tears come to her eyes. Ba consoles her, and the woman breaks down into sobs. Later, Gandhi rides in an open howdah on an elephant, lost in grave contemplation, with Shukla by his side, too intimidated to interrupt Gandhi's somber mood, which holds more fury than observed before except towards Ba. A ball is struck, revealing a lush, verdant field where white-clad players and English spectators watch under parasols, with Indian attendants discreetly serving beverages. After a four is struck, a batsman notices a vehicle hurrying near the clubhouse with an officer and streaming people, an Indian corporal driving, as a major stands on the back seat. The captain, wearing a clerical collar, resolute, looks down at Gandhi and shakes his head. Gandhi is seen in full, in a white loincloth, shawl, and sandals, his attire for existence. Charlie examines Gandhi, comprehends, and grins, prompting a small grin from Gandhi, who chuckles, and chuckles again. Charlie turns to the guard, who hesitantly unlocks the cell. Charlie enters, perches on a stool opposite Gandhi, his long legs awkwardly filling the space between them.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Gandhi is seated cross-legged, with listening done in a way that opens the heart, while a mass of villagers stoically waits outside the dwelling for their case to be heard. Meha's attempt to speak unemotionally is made, but under Gandhi's sympathetic gaze, his despair is broken through. Near breakdown, gestures are made by Meha around the empty house, unable to continue, and a nod is given by him. The crude dwelling where almost nothing remains is looked around by Gandhi. Two young men, perhaps seventeen and older, a girl about sixteen, and Meha's wife, who sits near Ba, are present. The two women listen together, but a defeated look is worn by Meha's wife, with unkempt hair and a dirty sari. A nod is given by Gandhi, bleak words that offer no false hope are spoken by him, and Meha's wife is glanced at by him, who lowers her head as water comes to her eyes. Ba comforts her, and into sobs, the woman breaks down. Later, in an open howdah on an elephant, Gandhi is ridden, lost in sober reflection, with Shukla by his side, intimidated too much to interrupt Gandhi's dark mood, containing more anger than seen before except towards Ba. A ball is hit, revealing a lush, verdant pitch where white-garbed players and English onlookers watch under parasols, with discreet serving of drinks by Indian servants. After a four is hit, a car hurrying near the clubhouse is noticed by a batsman, with an officer and streaming people inside, being driven by an Indian corporal, as a major stands on the back seat. The captain, wearing a clerical collar, determinedly looks down at Gandhi and shakes his head. Gandhi is seen in full, in a white loincloth, shawl, and sandals, his attire for life. Gandhi is studied by Charlie, understood by him, and a grin is prompted, from which a small grin is given by Gandhi, who laughs, and laughs again. The guard is turned to by Charlie, who hesitantly unlocks the cell. A stool opposite Gandhi is entered and sat on by Charlie, his long legs awkwardly filling the space between them.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Gandhi sits cross-legged, listening intently, while villagers wait outside for their cases. Meha, struggling emotionally, gestures around the empty house. Gandhi observes the sparse dwelling. Two young men, a sixteen-year-old girl, Meha's wife, and Ba are present. Meha's wife, disheveled in a dirty sari, looks defeated. Gandhi nods, offering no false hope, and she lowers her head, tearful. Ba comforts her as she sobs. Later, Gandhi rides on an elephant, deeply reflective, with Shukla by his side, intimidated by Gandhi's dark mood. A lush pitch reveals white-garbed players watched by English onlookers and Indian servants. A car approaches, carrying a major and an Indian corporal. The captain in a clerical collar sees Gandhi in his white loincloth and shawl. Charlie studies Gandhi, grins, prompting Gandhi to laugh. Charlie enters the cell, awkwardly filling the space opposite Gandhi.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Gandhi sits cross-legged, listening attentively while villagers wait outside to be heard. Meha tries to speak but breaks down under Gandhi's gaze, gesturing at the empty house. Gandhi observes the sparse dwelling; two young men, a girl, and Meha's wife sit nearby, the women listening. Meha's wife appears defeated, with unkempt hair and a dirty sari. Gandhi speaks without false hope, glancing at her as she tears up. Ba comforts her as she sobs. Later, Gandhi rides an elephant, lost in reflection, with Shukla beside him. A ball game unfolds on a lush pitch, with white-clad players and English spectators under parasols, served by discreet Indian servants. A car rushes by with an officer and people, an Indian corporal driving. A captain shakes his head at Gandhi, who wears a white loincloth, shawl, and sandals. Charlie studies and grins at him, making Gandhi laugh. Charlie enters Gandhi's cell, sitting awkwardly opposite him.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Sitting cross-legged in a posture of deep meditation and attentive listening, Gandhi exudes an aura that opens the heart to compassion and understanding. Behind him, a large gathering of villagers waits patiently and stoically outside the modest dwelling, each person hoping for their turn to have their case heard. Meha, standing in front, attempts to speak in a controlled and emotionless tone; however, under the empathetic and understanding gaze of Gandhi, his suppressed despair begins to surface and become evident. In a state nearing emotional collapse, Meha gestures helplessly around the sparsely furnished and empty house, unable to continue speaking, and Gandhi acknowledges his struggle with a nod. Gazing around the crude and simple dwelling where almost no possessions remain, Gandhi takes in the scene. Present are two young men, perhaps around seventeen years or older, a girl likely about sixteen, and Meha's wife, all sitting near Ba. The two women listen intently together, yet there is an air of defeat about Meha's wife, her hair disheveled and her sari noticeably dirty. Gandhi nods, uttering words that are somber and bleak, offering no illusions or false hope. He then glances towards Meha's wife, who, overwhelmed by emotion, lowers her head as tears begin to pool in her eyes. Ba reaches out to comfort her gently, causing the woman to break down completely into deep, uncontrollable sobs.

Later, Gandhi is seen riding thoughtfully in an open howdah on an elephant. He is deep in sober reflection, with Shukla sitting by his side, too intimidated to disrupt Gandhi's dark and intense mood, which seems to contain more anger than anyone has observed before, except perhaps in moments directed towards Ba. Meanwhile, on a lush, verdant cricket pitch nearby, a ball is struck with precision, capturing the attention of white-clad players and English spectators who watch under the shade of parasols, while Indian servants unobtrusively serve drinks. After a skillful four is hit, a batsman notices a car making its way hurriedly towards the clubhouse, an officer visible with an entourage of people streaming behind, driven by an Indian corporal as a major stands in the back seat. The captain, notably marked by his clerical collar and a look of determination, observes Gandhi and shakes his head slightly. Gandhi stands in stark contrast, seen fully in his simple yet significant attire of a white loincloth, a shawl draped over his shoulders, and sandals on his feet, his chosen attire that symbolizes his way of life. Charlie, observing Gandhi intently, comes to an understanding and breaks into a grin, which prompts a small grin in return from Gandhi, leading to shared laughter that breaks the tension. Charlie then turns to the guard, who, after a moment of hesitation, unlocks the cell door. Entering, Charlie sits down on a stool placed opposite Gandhi, his long legs awkwardly occupying the limited space between them.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Sitting cross-legged in a posture that embodies deep meditation and attentive listening, Gandhi exudes an undeniable aura that opens the heart wide to compassion and fosters understanding. Behind him, there is a large assembly of villagers gathered together, waiting with patient and stoic demeanor outside the modest dwelling. Each individual there harbors the hope of having their opportunity to present their case and be heard. Positioned at the forefront is Meha, who endeavors to speak in a voice that is controlled and devoid of emotion; however, under the empathetic and understanding gaze of Gandhi, Meha’s suppressed despair begins to surface and become evident. In a state nearing emotional collapse, Meha gestures helplessly around the sparsely furnished and empty house, finding himself unable to continue speaking. Gandhi acknowledges his struggle with a simple but knowing nod. As his eyes casually sweep across the crude and simple dwelling where hardly any possessions remain, Gandhi takes in the scene. Present within this space are two young men, probably around seventeen years of age or possibly older, a girl who appears to be likely about sixteen, and Meha's wife, all of whom are seated near Ba. The two women listen together with earnest attention, yet there is an air of defeat that surrounds Meha's wife; her hair is disheveled, and her sari is noticeably dirty. Gandhi nods and speaks words that are somber and bleak, offering neither illusions nor false hope. He then turns his gaze towards Meha's wife, who, overwhelmed by the rising tide of her emotions, lowers her head as tears begin to pool and brim in her eyes. In response, Ba reaches out to comfort her gently, causing the woman to break down completely, succumbing to deep and uncontrollable sobs.

Later on, Gandhi is observed riding thoughtfully in an open howdah atop an elephant. He is immersed in deep, sober reflection, with Shukla seated by his side, feeling too intimidated to disrupt Gandhi's dark and intense mood, a mood that seems to simmer with more anger than anyone has noticed before, except perhaps in rare moments directed towards Ba. Meanwhile, on a nearby lush and verdant cricket pitch, a ball is struck with precision, catching the attention of white-clad players and English spectators who watch from the comfort of shade provided by their parasols, while Indian servants unobtrusively serve refreshing drinks. After a skillful four is hit, a batsman observes a car making its way hurriedly towards the clubhouse, with an officer visible amongst an entourage of people streaming behind. It is being driven by an Indian corporal as a major stands in the back seat. The captain, distinguished by his clerical collar and an expression of determination, observes Gandhi and shakes his head ever so slightly. Gandhi stands out in stark contrast, seen fully in his simple yet significant attire of a white loincloth, a shawl draped over his shoulders, and sandals on his feet, an attire that symbolizes his chosen way of life. Charlie, observing Gandhi intently, arrives at an understanding and breaks into a grin, which prompts a small grin in return from Gandhi, leading to shared laughter that effectively breaks the tension. Charlie then turns to face the guard, who, after a moment of hesitation, unlocks the cell door. Entering, Charlie takes a seat on a stool placed opposite Gandhi, his long legs awkwardly occupying the confined space between them.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Gandhi sits quietly on the floor, his legs crossed, while focusing intently on listening in a manner that seems to open the heart of anyone speaking to him. In the background, a large group of villagers stands patiently, waiting outside the dwelling, showing their readiness to have their concerns addressed. As Meha attempts to convey his situation without becoming emotional, the empathetic gaze of Gandhi seems to penetrate Meha's defenses, causing his feelings of despair to surface. Meha, on the verge of breaking down, gestures broadly around the nearly empty house, his voice faltering, indicating his inability to continue speaking. Gandhi, taking in the scene, casts his eyes around the primitive dwelling, noting the absence of belongings or comforts. Within the room, there are two young men, one appearing to be around seventeen and the other slightly older, a teenage girl of about sixteen, and Meha's wife, all of whom are sitting near Ba. The two women, Meha's wife and Ba, listen intently together, but the wife appears particularly defeated, her hair disheveled and her sari dirty. Acknowledging the depth of the situation, Gandhi nods somberly and delivers words that are honest but devoid of any false promises, casting a glance at Meha's wife, who reacts by lowering her head and tears welling up in her eyes. In response, Ba reaches out to comfort her, causing Meha's wife to release her pent-up emotion and break down into sobs. Later, Gandhi finds himself riding in an open howdah atop an elephant, deep in sober reflection, with Shukla beside him, who is too intimidated by Gandhi's unusually dark mood to speak. This mood, infused with anger, is more intense than any other that has surfaced except when directed towards Ba. In a change of scene, a ball is struck on a lush, green cricket pitch where players clad in white and English spectators, shaded under parasols, watch the game as Indian servants move discreetly among them, serving drinks. After the ball is hit to the boundary for four runs, a batsman takes notice of a car speeding towards the clubhouse. The car, driven by an Indian corporal, carries an officer and a group of people streaming behind it, with a major standing prominently in the back seat. Observing these events, the team captain, distinguished by his clerical collar, looks down at Gandhi with determination and shakes his head. Gandhi stands there fully visible in his simple attire of a white loincloth, shawl, and sandals, which represents his lifelong commitment. Charlie, observing Gandhi thoughtfully, comprehends the gravity of his presence and breaks into a grin, which elicits a small grin from Gandhi as well, followed by laughter and then another round of laughter. Charlie then turns his attention to the guard, who, after a moment's hesitation, unlocks the cell door. Entering the cell, Charlie takes a seat on a stool opposite Gandhi, his long legs awkwardly positioned in the confined space between them.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Gandhi sits cross-legged, attentively listening to Meha, whose emotions crumble under Gandhi's sympathetic gaze. As Meha gestures to the empty house, unable to continue, Gandhi observes the sparse dwelling and the presence of two young men, a teenage girl, and Meha's wife, who appears defeated, with Ba and the two women listening. Gandhi acknowledges the grim situation with bleak words, prompting Meha's wife to lower her head in tears, comforted by Ba. Later, Gandhi, pensive and reflecting deeply, rides on an elephant with Shukla, who dares not interrupt Gandhi's somber and angry mood. Meanwhile, a cricket game unfolds with English spectators and Indian servants, until a car speeds by with an officer and crowd. The captain, clerical collar visible, shakes his head at Gandhi, clad in his simple attire. Charlie observes Gandhi, shares a mutual grin, and exchanges laughter with him. He then convinces the hesitant guard to unlock the cell, enters, and sits awkwardly opposite Gandhi.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Gandhi sits cross-legged, listening in a way that opens the heart, embodying the compassion for which he is renowned, while behind him a mass of villagers waits stoically outside the dwelling for their case to be heard, illustrating the widespread reliance on Gandhi's wisdom. Meha tries to speak unemotionally, but under Gandhi's sympathetic gaze, his despair breaks through, much like many who felt comforted by Gandhi's presence during India's struggle for independence. Near breakdown, Meha gestures around the empty house, unable to continue, and he nods, acknowledging the hardship faced by his family. Gandhi looks around the crude dwelling where almost nothing remains, a reflection of the poverty that plagued rural India. Two young men, perhaps seventeen and older, a girl about sixteen, and Meha's wife, sitting near Ba, who is affectionately known as Kasturba Gandhi, are present. The two women listen together, but Meha's wife looks defeated, with unkempt hair and a dirty sari, emblematic of the struggles endured by women in a patriarchal society. Gandhi nods, speaking bleak words that offer no false hope, mindful of the realistic approach he always advocated, and glances at Meha's wife, who lowers her head as water comes to her eyes. Ba comforts her, demonstrating her nurturing nature, and the woman breaks down into sobs. Later, Gandhi rides in an open howdah on an elephant, a traditional mode of Indian royal transport, lost in sober reflection, with Shukla by his side, too intimidated to interrupt Gandhi's dark mood, which contains more anger than seen before except towards Ba, illustrating occasional tensions in their partnership. A ball is hit, revealing a lush, verdant pitch where white-garbed players engage in a cricket match, a legacy of British colonial influence, and English onlookers watch under parasols, with Indian servants discreetly serving drinks in a scene of colonial leisure. After a four is hit, a batsman notices a car hurrying near the clubhouse with an officer and streaming people, an Indian corporal driving, as a major stands on the back seat, highlighting the military presence often interwoven with civilian life during British rule. The captain, wearing a clerical collar, determined, looks down at Gandhi and shakes his head, indicating a possible moral conflict. Gandhi is seen in full, in a white loincloth, shawl, and sandals, his attire for life that symbolizes simplicity and self-reliance. Charlie studies Gandhi, understands the depth of his conviction, and grins, prompting a small grin from Gandhi, who laughs, and laughs again, a rare moment of levity. Charlie turns to the guard, who hesitantly unlocks the cell, a testament to the reverence and caution Gandhi's presence inspired. Charlie enters, sits on a stool opposite Gandhi, his long legs awkwardly filling the space between them, in a situation reminiscent of Gandhi's many dialogues with those who did not initially share his views.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The dragon perches awkwardly, staring in a way that tickles the sky, while beside it a band of foxes dances joyfully inside the castle for their cake to be cooked. Zoe struggles to sing musically, but under the dragon's curious glance, her happiness bursts forth. Nearly laughing, Zoe waves toward the crowded barn, eager to continue, and she grins. The dragon peeks around the ornate palace where almost everything shines. Two old women, perhaps seventy and younger, a boy about six, and Zoe's brother, standing far from Ray, are absent. The two men chuckle separately, but Zoe's brother appears victorious, with styled hair and a pristine suit. The dragon grins, uttering cheerful phrases that convey no false applause, and winks at Zoe's brother, who lifts his head as fireworks light up the sky. Ray praises him, and the man bursts into cheers. Earlier, the dragon races on a swift chariot on a highway, engulfed in light-hearted contemplation, with Terry by its side, too fearful to disturb the dragon's sunny disposition, which contains more joy than shown before except towards Ray. A feather is blown, revealing a barren, desert field where black-clad dancers and French tourists relax under umbrellas, with Japanese chefs openly serving meals. After a kite is flown, a pilot watches a bicycle dawdling around the garden with a musician and singing cats, a French sergeant conducting, as a gardener sits on the front basket. The referee, wearing a jester's hat, elated, looks up at the dragon and bounces his toes. The dragon is spotted in halves, in a black tuxedo, cape, and boots, its outfit for parties. Alex ignores the dragon, misunderstands, and frowns, causing a wide frown from the dragon, who cries, and cries again. Alex approaches the poet, who confidently locks the door. Alex exits, stands on a ladder beside the dragon, her short arms gracefully stretching beneath them.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Gandhi sits cross-legged, listening intently to Meha, who struggles to hold back despair, gesturing at his empty home. Surrounding them are two young men, a girl, and Meha's wife, who appears defeated and breaks down into sobs, comforted by Ba. Gandhi offers somber words, avoiding false hope. Later, riding an elephant, Gandhi is deep in thought, with Shukla beside him, reflecting more anger than usual. Meanwhile, a cricket game unfolds with English spectators and discreet Indian servants. As a car approaches, an officer and major arrive, catching the players' attention. The captain, in clerical garb, observes Gandhi, now in simple attire, and shakes his head. Charlie, studying Gandhi, grins, leading to shared laughter. He enters Gandhi's cell, filling the space awkwardly with his long legs, setting the stage for their interaction.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: Charlie enters sits on a stool opposite Gandhi his long legs awkwardly filling the space between them Charlie turns to the guard who hesitantly unlocks the cell Gandhi understands and grins prompting a small grin from Gandhi who laughs and laughs again Charlie studies Gandhi is seen in full in a white loincloth shawl and sandals his attire for life The captain wearing a clerical collar determined looks down at Gandhi and shakes his head an Indian corporal driving as a major stands on the back seat After a four is hit a batsman notices a car hurrying near the clubhouse with an officer and streaming people A ball is hit revealing a lush verdant pitch where whitegarbed players and English onlookers watch under parasols with Indian servants discreetly serving drinks Later Gandhi rides in an open howdah on an elephant lost in sober reflection with Shukla by his side too intimidated to interrupt Gandhi's dark mood which contains more anger than seen before except towards Ba Ba comforts her and the woman breaks down into sobs Gandhi nods speaking bleak words that offer no false hope and glances at Meha's wife who lowers her head as water comes to her eyes The two women listen together but Meha's wife looks defeated with unkempt hair and a dirty sari Two young men perhaps seventeen and older a girl about sixteen and Meha's wife sitting near Ba are present Gandhi looks around the crude dwelling where almost nothing remains Near breakdown Meha gestures around the empty house unable to continue and he nods Meha tries to speak unemotionally but under Gandhi's sympathetic gaze his despair breaks through Gandhi sits crosslegged listening in a way that opens the heart while behind him a mass of villagers waits stoically outside the dwelling for their case to be heard
